Optimizing routes reduces fuel costs and ensures timely waste processing.

title: Floating Plastic Waste Collection & Recycling Bin Deployment
desc_split:
An environmental organization maintains a network of floating waste collection points along riverways (<loc_customer>). Service boats (<capacity>) must:  
- Deploy empty recycling containers (<demand_linehaul>)  
- Retrieve full containers of plastic waste (<demand_backhaul>)  
- Sequence stops adaptively based on real-time container fill levels  
- Complete routes within <distance_limit> nautical miles due to fuel constraints  
The mixed nature allows prioritizing either deployment or collection first based on urgency.
label: vrpmbl

title: Industrial Gas Cylinder Distribution & Empty Recovery
desc_split:
A gas supplier services manufacturing plants (<loc_customer>) requiring both:  
- Delivery of full pressurized gas cylinders (<demand_linehaul>)  
- Collection of empty cylinders (<demand_backhaul>)  
Fleet trucks (<capacity>) must:  
- Interleave deliveries and pickups based on plant production schedules  
- Maintain total cylinder count (full + empty) below truck capacity  
- Limit routes to <distance_limit> km due to DOT driver hour regulations
label: vrpmbl

title: Mobile COVID-19 Testing & Medical Waste Collection
desc_split:
A healthcare provider operates mobile testing units that:  
- Deliver test kits to community centers (<demand_linehaul>)  
- Collect biological samples for lab analysis (<demand_backhaul>)  
Medical transport vans (<capacity>) must:  
- Handle temperature-sensitive cargo in any sequence  
- Comply with <distance_limit> km biohazard transport regulations  
- Never mix fresh kits and samples beyond capacity limits
label: vrpmbl

title: Urban Beehive Rotation & Honey Harvest Problem
desc_split:
An apiary service manages pollination contracts by:  
- Deploying active hives to farms (<demand_linehaul>)  
- Retrieving hives for honey extraction (<demand_backhaul>)  
Specialized trucks (<capacity>) must:  
- Balance hive transport with honey weight constraints  
- Complete routes within <distance_limit> km to minimize bee stress  
- Sequence stops based on bloom cycles and harvest readiness  

Each scenario emphasizes:  
1. **Capacity (C)**: Explicit load constraints for combined deliveries/pickups  
2. **Mixed Backhauls (MB)**: Flexible sequencing of delivery/collection tasks  
3. **Distance Limits (L)**: Route length restrictions without time windows  
4. **No TW/O/B/MD**: Avoids time windows, open routes, strict backhaul sequencing, or multiple depots
label: vrpmbl

title: Mobile EV Charging Station Deployment & Depleted Battery Collection
desc_split:
A green energy company operates mobile charging units to service electric vehicles (EVs) across a city. Each truck (capacity <capacity>) starts at a depot (<loc_depot>) and must:  
- Deliver charged battery packs to designated swap stations (<loc_customer>, demand <demand_linehaul>).  
- Collect depleted batteries from the same or other stations (<demand_backhaul>).  
Routes can mix deliveries and pickups freely, but trucks cannot exceed their battery capacity or travel beyond <distance_limit> km per shift due to operational constraints.  
The goal is to minimize total distance while ensuring all stations are serviced without overloading vehicles.
label: vrpmbl

title: Floating Market Grocery Supply & Spoilage Collection
desc_split:
In a riverine community, boats (capacity <capacity>) distribute fresh produce from a central hub (<loc_depot>) to floating markets (<loc_customer>). Each market requires deliveries (<demand_linehaul>) and may return spoiled goods (<demand_backhaul>).  
Boats can sequence deliveries/collections flexibly but must complete routes within <distance_limit> km due to fuel limits. The challenge is to balance inventory turnover and minimize travel time on winding waterways.
label: vrpmbl

title: Antarctic Research Station Resupply & Waste Evacuation
desc_split:
A logistics firm supports research bases in Antarctica using snowcats (capacity <capacity>). Vehicles must:  
- Deliver supplies from a coastal depot (<loc_depot>) to inland stations (<loc_customer>, demand <demand_linehaul>).  
- Collect recyclables and waste from stations (<demand_backhaul>).  
Mixed sequences are allowed, but extreme cold limits daily travel to <distance_limit> km. Routes must avoid overloading while servicing all stations before blizzard season.
label: vrpmbl

title: Urban Vertical Farm Nutrient Delivery & Harvest Collection
desc_split:
A hydroponic farm network uses electric vans (capacity <capacity>) to:  
- Deliver liquid nutrients to rooftop farms (<loc_customer>, demand <demand_linehaul>).  
- Collect harvested produce from the same sites (<demand_backhaul>).  
Vans can alternate deliveries/pickups but are restricted to <distance_limit> km per charge. The system aims to minimize mileage while ensuring no farm runs out of nutrients or overflows with harvest.
label: vrpmbl

title: Film Festival Equipment Logistics & Media Return
desc_split:
During a city-wide film festival, trucks (capacity <capacity>) transport equipment from a warehouse (<loc_depot>) to venues (<loc_customer>, demand <demand_linehaul>) while collecting recorded media (<demand_backhaul>).  
Routes can freely mix deliveries/pickups but must finish within <distance_limit> km due to tight scheduling. The objective is to service all venues without delays or vehicle overloads.

desc_split: A company operates mobile charging units to service electric vehicles (EVs) in urban areas. Routes from the depot (<loc_depot>) must comply with strict travel distance limits (<distance_limit> km) for safety inspections, with no precedence constraints between deliveries and pickups.

title: Mobile EV Charging Station Deployment & Battery Swap Problem
desc_split: A company operates mobile electric vehicle (EV) charging stations that visit parking lots and urban hubs to recharge EVs and swap depleted batteries. Each service vehicle (capacity: `<capacity>` batteries) starts at a depot (`<loc_depot>`) and visits `<num_customer>` locations (`<loc_customer>`), where some stops require delivering fresh batteries (`<demand_linehaul>`) and others involve collecting depleted ones (`<demand_backhaul>`). Routes must respect battery-swap demand sequences (mixed order) and a maximum travel distance (`<distance_limit>`) to ensure timely returns for recharging. The goal is to minimize total distance while ensuring no vehicle exceeds its battery-carrying capacity.
label: vrpmbl

title: Antarctic Research Station Resupply & Waste Evacuation Problem
desc_split: A supply ship must deliver scientific equipment and provisions to remote Antarctic research stations while collecting waste and recyclables for return. The ship (capacity: `<capacity>` tons) departs from a coastal base (`<loc_depot>`) and visits `<num_customer>` stations (`<loc_customer>`), with each station requiring either supplies (`<demand_linehaul>`) or waste pickup (`<demand_backhaul>`). Due to harsh conditions, each route must stay within a fuel-efficient distance (`<distance_limit>`). Mixed backhauls allow flexible sequencing (e.g., delivering supplies to Station A before collecting waste from Station B). The objective is to serve all stations without exceeding capacity or distance constraints.

title: Urban Vertical Farm Nutrient Delivery & Harvest Collection Problem
desc_split: A logistics firm serves urban vertical farms by delivering liquid nutrients and collecting harvested produce. title: Fishing Fleet Support Vessel Routing Problem

title: Mobile EV Battery Swap & Depleted Battery Collection
desc_split:
A network of electric vehicle (EV) charging stations requires regular battery swaps for taxis and delivery fleets. Service vans (capacity <capacity>) depart from a central depot (<loc_depot>) to:  
- Deliver fresh batteries (<demand_linehaul>) to stations at <loc_customer>  
- Collect depleted batteries (<demand_backhaul>) from the same or different stations  
Routes must optimize the sequence of deliveries/pickups while respecting:  
✓ Vehicle weight limits when carrying both fresh and dead batteries  
✓ Maximum daily travel distance (<distance_limit>) due to shift constraints  
✓ Mixed ordering (some stations may need delivery before pickup, others vice versa)  
```

```
**Scenario 2:** Antarctic Research Station Resupply & Waste Evacuation  
A supply ship coordinates ice-road truck routes from coastal depot (<loc_depot>) to:  
- Deliver fuel/equipment (<demand_linehaul>) to <num_customer> inland bases  
- Retrieve experimental waste (<demand_backhaul>) for offshore disposal  
Critical constraints:  
✓ Vehicles must complete round trips within <distance_limit> due to extreme weather windows  
✓ Cargo capacity (<capacity>) must account for combined supplies and waste  
✓ Mixed sequencing - some bases require immediate waste removal before accepting new supplies  
```

```
**Scenario 3:** Urban Vertical Farm Nutrient Delivery & Harvest Collection  
Hydroponic skyscraper farms require daily logistics from a processing center (<loc_depot>):  
- Deliver liquid nutrients (<demand_linehaul>) to towers at <loc_customer>  
- Collect mature produce (<demand_backhaul>) for distribution  
Routing challenges:  
✓ Refrigerated trucks have strict weight (<capacity>) and distance (<distance_limit>) limits  
✓ Some towers may require harvest before accepting new nutrients to free storage space  
✓ Time-sensitive perishables demand efficient mixed-order routing  
```

```
**Scenario 4:** Fishing Fleet Support Vessel Routing Problem  
A mothership (<loc_depot>) coordinates supply runs to <num_customer> fishing boats:  
- Deliver ice/fuel (<demand_linehaul>)  
- Collect catches (<demand_backhaul>) for processing  
Operational constraints:  
✓ Support vessels have cold storage capacity (<capacity>) for both supplies and fish  
✓ Must complete all operations within <distance_limit> due to fuel constraints  
✓ Dynamic sequencing - some boats need fuel before surrendering catch, others vice versa  
```

```
**Scenario 5:** Hazardous Chemical Delivery & Waste Collection Problem  
Specialized tanker trucks operate from a depot (<loc_depot>) to:  
- Deliver industrial chemicals (<demand_linehaul>) to factories  
- Collect spent solvents (<demand_backhaul>) for recycling  
Safety-driven requirements:  
✓ Strict compartmentalized capacity (<capacity>) for different hazard classes  
✓ Routes limited to <distance_limit> to minimize accident risks  
✓ Flexible sequencing - some facilities require waste removal before accepting new chemicals  
```

Each scenario emphasizes:  
- **C**: Explicit capacity constraints for combined loads  
- **MB**: Natural mixing of delivery/pickup sequences  
- **L**: Hard distance limits without time windows  
- Avoids TW/O/B/MD constraints as specified
label: vrpmbl
